revised_title: Determining the Limitations of Telescopes in Observing Small Angles and Diameters of Celestial and Terrestrial Objects
tldr: The author, William Herschel, conducted experiments to determine the smallest angle and diameter of celestial and terrestrial objects that can be observed using a reflecting telescope. He used various objects, such as pins and silver and sealing-wax globules, to test the telescope's capabilities. The results showed that a telescope with sufficient power can show the disk of a faint object when the angle it subtends at the naked eye is as small as 0°653.
